article.headline: Trump tweets, âDonât be afraid of Covid,â sparking heated Twitter exchanges
article.body: As President Trump prepared to leave Walter Reed Medical Center on Monday, he tweeted this upbeat message out to the public: “ âFeeling really good! Donât be afraid of Covid. Donât let it dominate your life. We have developed, under the Trump administration, some really great drugs & knowledge.â ” â President Donald Trump The phrase âDonât be afraid of Covidâ became a trending topic on Twitter TWTR, -0.23% Â on Monday afternoon, with many people accusing the presidential post of being tone deaf or irresponsible, considering that close to 210,000 Americans and counting have died from COVID-19 this year, and the U.S. has recorded 7.4 million cases â leading the world in both pandemic metrics. iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } Whatâs more, many people have reported suffering coronavirus-related health problems continuing for months after their initial diagnoses, raising concerns about the long-term effects of the virus. Read: A lung doctor on what sheâs learning about coronavirus âlong haulersâ: shortness of breath, fatigue, and depression but also âimprovement over timeâ Supporters of the president responded positively to his tweet. iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } Still, the overwhelming response on Twitter was negative, with critics pointing out that Trump was given COVID-19 treatments usually reserved for people who are more seriously ill than Trump has been depicted as being, as well as experimental therapies that most people donât have access to. It should be noted that an estimated 30 million Americans under 65 donât have health insurance, according to 2018 CDC data. And another 5.4 million people who were laid off from their jobs during the pandemic are uninsured, according to a July study by the Families USA advocacy group. Read:The unemployment rate has gone down, but fewer Americans expect to return to their old jobs Plus, about 33.6 million Americans, or 24% of U.S. civilian workers, donât have access to paid sick leave in the event that they or someone in their household gets sick. iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } The president returned to the White House on Monday evening, mounting a staircase and lingering on a balcony long enough to see off Marine One, pose for photographs and record a video message. He removed his mask almost immediately. Here is what MarketWatch has reported about the presidentâs health, his treatments and the potential impact of his diagnosis on the election so far. His doctor noted he may not be âout of the woods yet.â
